title: 'wearable' T60b Power Armor from Fallout 4 Brotherhood of Steel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS.
THIS PROJECT IS ON PAUSE - I am working on my master thesis right now, so if anyone wants the CAD files from this project (Autodesk Inventor, .ipt), feel free to contact me. I want to build / model a complete Power Armor from Fallout 4 - because this is quiete a large project with many problems. For the first models I just took directly the game models. Many fields are involved - not only 3D/ CAD-modeling, also robotics (hand operation, opening mechanism for frame) and some parts of genral mechanical prozesses (for example the complete leg assembly). The plan is to let the hand rotate about a range of 180°. Have Fun.
 
 UPDATE 12/19/2016
 I just uploaded the near final version of the hand. It now has 2 mounts for 28BYJ-48 steppers motors inside the palm to operate the fingers - I plan an using one for the thumb and the other for the rest of the 4 fingers. I printed a first prototype and found out that the joints I printed (100% infill) were way to stiff.
I also added the first part of Update 0.5 - the lower arm. It has all parts to make the wrist rotate (including 2 additional 28BYJ-48 motor mounts) but the way up the arm is not completed yet.
   
UPDATE 02/02/2016
For all people wondering, what I am on to: I just uploaded a version of the hand with bigger tolerances.
Also I am restarting the lower arm section from scratch (again) - I working on a rotation-mechanism for the hand and uploaded a picture how the final version could look like.
In this design the three small gears (only one will be driven by a stepper motor) also center the hand part to the lower arm.
 
 
 
UPDATE 0.4 01/08/2016
I just finished the (right) hands first version. Shoutouts to the people who inspired me are mentioned in the last update. I re-organized the download-folder and added all old files to the 'LEGACY'-Archive. The most recent version only contains the hand (Version 0.4) which I build from scratch.
For assembly you will need parts 001, 002 and 003 (index+ring finger) two and part 015 (the joint - has to be printed in flexible filament) fifteen times. Part 016 (mold) is for those people who can't print with flexible filament and instead want to build the joints with silicone.
Also you will need some sort of cord to actuate the fingeres, the holes are sized 2 mm - I'd suggest some nylon- or fishing-cord. The wrist is designed to be attached to the lower arm with two M8 hex-head-screws.
I haven't printed the hand yet - if you want to print print one finger and the joints first to check if it actually works. I remodeld some parts for bigger tolerances in all connections.
Next point on the agenda: the lower arm. UPDATE 12/27/2015
The work on the robotic hand is going on slowly - but I decided to go for something like this:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:242639
For now I have added a rough model and picture for the concept I am going to build for the legs / feet. After long times of tinkering I couldn't get it worked out with printed parts only. So I designed feet made from wood and added a 'skeleton' made from aluminium profiles and printed braces. The opening mechanism for the lower and upper legs are operated by bowden cables.
Regards to XRobots for the inspirtion - visit his website:
http://xrobots.co.uk/
I added a near-final version of the hand. Now I am mostly working on the lower arm (which will probably be nothing like the original frame, less detailed, more practical to strap on some armor and house the servos and circuit board to manage the hand movement). ALPHA/Preview 0.4 11/25/2015
This preview-version only contains the parts of the right (robotic armor-frame) hand. Part 003 is the hands complete assembly, 004 is the lower arm, 004a-004k are all parts of the hand and parts 005 and 006 are the parts from which the lower arm is made (= assembled in 004) with the 'opening-mechanism' when entering the power armor. UPDATE 0.3 11/21/2015
  • cut 001 T60B-helmet into 9 smaller pieces to make it actual printable (ATTENTION: single-shell model)
  • reworked 013, 014, 016, 017 to make the model working with an actual joint
    • UPDATE 0.2 11/20/2015
  • reworked 008 "T60B-chest_back-upper02" with model parts from power armor frame to make it actual wearable, closed holes in mesh, added supports to attach shoulder-armor
  • reworked 012 "012 T60B-chest_front-upper02" with model parts from power armor frame to make it compatible with 008 "T60B-chest_back-upper02"
  • reworked 013, 014, 016, 017 to make the model "theoretical" wearable, connected lower leg + foot, reinforeced with parts from the power armor frame model
  • added Texture_PowerArmorFrame, maybe print it on a morph-suite and use it to mimic frame
     
     
    UPDATE 0.1 11/19/2015
    I have added T60b-wearable-0.1.rar archive whicht contains the whole T60b armor (without frame) broken into 17 individual pieces which could be scaled and printed to fit your body.
    • Known issues:
  • parts need further break-down into smaller pieces to be printed on smaller printers
  • poor resolution

comments.author: NaesNagorb

comments.text: I was aware of the hand being placed in the forearm months before the game came out xD Analized many trailers and animations alongside Photoreference. I even theorized at one point that some power armor sets could be like centry bots made by the institute ( which would later be half confirmed with the reveal trailer where they show synths). BTW The ''robotic'' hand is no problem. You could actually build a puppet like hand with some cables and springs in order to operate the fingers from within the suit. My Whole concern with this armor is that it's larger than the user and you can't simply print it to fit your average size because in order for your limbs to fit in the hands and feet of the suit you'd have to scale it down thus drastically reducing the helmet size and preventing you to fit it on your head. So either you have a really small head or you are going to print a Bobble head like version of the suit. To print it in actual size would mean building an actual frame with some metal strips and strapping on armor pieces as you go. Perhaps strap a brick to each foot and hollow out the 3d printed foot to house it. I can't immagine the feet of this armor being very neat but the rest should prove to be alright to replicate

comments.text: no... It's not ''the same'' as the in game model was not meant for full scale print. If you were to print the in game model full scale in real life you'd end up with a low poly version of the in game model. There are plenty of round elements on the armor that look fine in the game thanks to anti aliasing and a good texture on top but in reality you'd have most of the round elements on the armor being jagged. Take a look at the model and watch how the 2 round elements in the ear area of the helmet arent round but instead poligonal.

comments.text: Don't know about that. Printing the whole frame seems like a huge effort. Besides the mesh doesn't differentiate between Soft parts ( like elboy and knee joints) and solid ''metal'' parts. Even the hand is just one huge chunk. Think it would probably be best to print the individual finger elements and then secure them to some sort of rubber glove. Still searching for the right kind of rubber or silicone to purchase to cover the parts of the armor where ther's a joint or a disconect between armor plates. Are you sure that printing the whole frame is a good idea ? Is it sturdy enough to withstand the friction of movement and to support the armor plates ? If you do put out a file for the frame with all the various clipping errors out of the way what do you plan on doing for the neck, elbow and knee joints ? They are all part of the same model so you should cut out those segments should you not ? Forgive me if I seem neurotic but there are just to many things that could turn out wrong late in the production process. Even the in game model was ''sloppy'' for some aspects. The animation in which you climb in the suit is riddled of clipping errors and pieces of armor thatgo through eachother or through parts of the frame. What are your thoughs on building a slim exoskeleton to support the armor as a pose to printing the frame ? ( If i'm going to have a support for the suit i'd prefer it being a reliable metal structure beneath the armor so that i could move with relative peace of mind without worrying about the plastic frame bending or cracking if i move the wrong way)

comments.text:

For this reason - till now- I splitted all parts (frame+armor) from each other, so you could (in theory) wear it like a medieval armor. Most parts are combined from frame and armor.

I'd like to have the hole model (or just the frame / exo skeleton) made from metal but I don't have the skills and material / tools to make it from metal.

title: Chevrolet Cavalier or Sunfire 95-02 Manual Shift Boot Bracket

description.text:
The plastic clips on my shifter boot bracket broke a couple of years ago and it've been driving with it removed. I finally got around to modeling a new one and it fits well. Let me know if this is at all useful to you! Insturctions:
1) Print the Bracket
2) Remove the pleather boot from the old, busted bracket by peeling it back from the glue
3) Use glue (I used hot melt glue) to secure the boot to the new bracket (see pic)
4) re-install in your car by pushing the bracket in until the clips engage.
5) Enjoy having your interior not look like it's ready for the wreckers. Pics:
1) Blue bracket = 2nd attempt test fit
2) old bracket vs new bracket top
2) old bracket vs new bracket bottom
3) Old bracket beside new bracket with boot draped over it
4) Gluing the new bracket
5) My Naked shifter
6) New bracket with boot installed.
Fin

Improved 92sho16's file: 1) Connector fits through hole, allowing it to actually connect to phone.
2) Raised height of base so connector could fit in slot without bending cord too much. As with his model, this is designed to fit the Nexus 6P with a TPU case but a small spacer in the rear could allow for a phone without a case. The hole is sized to fit the charging cords that come with the phone, I'm not sure if any after market ones will work. My case:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B015P3KNGW?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00
But any similar one should work. To make this semi-permanent I verified correct angle and protrusion of the connector and then squirted a bunch of hot glue in through the bottom. Also added hot glue where the cord comes out so that when the phone is not in the dock it doesn't want to fall over. Nexus 6P STL

Lyme Park is a magnificent house in Cheshire, England. This is a model of it which allows you to replicate the house using your 3D printer. If you like the look of this model then please check out my other models such as Wentworth Woodhouse and Heveningham Hall Brief History:
A house has stood on the site of Lyme Park since 1465 but it was demolished to make way for a new house built in the 16th century. The house was L-shaped and is still present today although it has been altered significantly with a new part of the house added at the back. It wasn't until 1820 that the rest of the house was added to make a courtyard in the middle. It was also around this time that the Palladian back to the house was added. Further alterations continued to be made but these were mainly internal or the addition of other buildings on the estate. In 1946, the house was given to the National Trust and members of the public can now view the house. The Model:
I have yet to be able to take an photos of my model but I shall do as soon as I can. This was modelled using accurate drawings and satellite images to ensure accuracy. I printed the model in PLA plastic with a layer height of 0.2mm and an infill of 10% however, I suggest that you use a much greater infill such as 20% or 25%. Also watch out for warping which can occur with large prints. To print this model it takes approximately 2.5hours. Enjoy!

title: Vertex K8400 Extrudeur optimisé
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
2 choses posent problème avec l'extrudeur de la VERTEX K8400 :
  • La position du trou de passage du filament trop près de la roue crantée. Du coup il est très difficile d'insérer un nouveau filament.
  • La largeur du levier métallique pour libérer le filament. Quand on comprime le ressort ça fait mal au doigt.
    • J'ai donc régler ces deux soucis en dessinant ce nouveau système.
    Objectif atteint : changement de fil hyper facile, et plus mal au doigt !
    Pas de soucis d'entrainement du filament sur un test de 7 heures.
Vous pourrez mettre un petit point de colle si nécessaire pour éviter le basculement de l'élargisseur de levier.

Merci Gribouille,
Je cherchais un extrudeur pour ma K8400. J'ai fait l'expérience du filament PVA soluble pour les support avec ma 2 ème buse. Le filament est plus mou que le PLA avec lesquels je n'ai pas eu de problème, même si j'ai aligné les extrudeurs au milieu des bobines, ce qui m'évite de freiner les bobines ... Le PVA passe la roulette dentée et si la buse se bouche, il s’agglutine avant la sortie et rien n'arrive à la buse. Je suis entrain de les imprimer et je les installe demain. A suivre ...
Cdlt,

Update 22/05/17 Build photos added.
Notes on this build,i would hold fire until final design is complete.
I fully intend to increase/make slight tolerances to account for the 8mm rods not being entirely straight.
Also due to the design of this thing,you must ensure that it is bolted down to a very flat surface,i am encountering slight issues with binding of the sliding blocks due to my surface/desk not being entirely level. More details,photos/videos coming shortly. UPDATE 18/05/17 Added 3x stepper enclosure,http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2330116
Update 07/12/15 build photos added. Update 23.11.15 Uploaded minion multi AIO z top, middle, and bottom spindle motor support block.
This will mount a 48volt 400watt 52mm spindle motor.
You will require 8mm bronzed bushings 12mm thick x10mm long x8mm inner. I have decided to make the z axis mounting modular for easy and quick changing of the tool being used.
MK8 extruder update coming shortly. Update 20.11.15
Project name clanged to minion multi AIO. The aim of this project is to create a simple but very flexible manufacturing device.
I have decided that i want to create a machine that is able to use any printing technology currently available.
Potentially the machine will do the following,but is not limited to. Laser engraving
FDM printing
SLA printing
SLS printing
CNC miling
Vinyl cutting But for now,this thing is a work in progress selective laser sintering machine. It can be used for laser diode engraving,and eventually laser sintering of polyamide power for 3D printing.
The build proposed chamber size is 400mm XY and 300mm Z axis. Only one z axis is required,as the powder is collected form the sides of the build chamber hoppers and spread over the build platform.
Auger screws are used to refill the hopper during each pass.
Unused/excess powder is pushed off the platform and into a collection draw under the machine for reuse.
The x and y axis are linked through the corner support blocks so that only one nema 17 stepper motor is needed per axis. You will require a ramps 1.4 controller PCB for movement control.
An arduino mega 2560 board r3
4 x DRV8825 Stepper Motor Drivers
Reprap Full Graphics LCD Controller X axis x 1 nema 17 motor
y axis x 1 nema 17 motor
z axis x 1 nema 17 motor Build platform axis sweep/hopper refill x 1 nema 17 motor I have uploaded the corner support block for now,and will upload the rest of the build shortly. Th corner support block requires 4 x 688 2rs bearings @ 8x16x5mm
8mm chrome plated rod is used for all linear rails,i have ordered 8x 500mm rods for the initial build. Proposed machine outside dimensions are 600x600 XY and 500mm Z I would recommend if able to print the parts in poly-carbonate or nylon filament,due to the extra resistance to the high temperatures of the build chamber. Your comments and feedback will make this project grow and flourish. (disclaimer) Please be aware that for safety reasons,the build chamber of this machine is intended to be made out of laser safe poly-carbonate or solid aluminum sheet.
I have rendered it in clear plastic purely for illustration purposes only.
Please ensure that you ware laser goggles at all times when messing around with laser diodes.if you don't own laser googles (buy them now) before attempting any tinkering.
You cant put a price on your eyesight,40 GBP or blind for life,its not and option. enjoy

Well, this is more of a experimental test of the printing time, material consumed, and cost for the current alpha Raspberry Pi. http://www.raspberrypi.org/ I know this is an alpha and will likely change, I believe their goal is around a credit card size. So, that will affect printing time, material consumed, and cost of the released version. I DO NOT HAVE AN ALPHA RASPBERRY PI, so I took some general guesses on the actual size and locations of the USB, power, etc... by measures a computer motherboard's dual USB and scaling that to the known pictures. Side A took 1 hour and 5 mins, while Side B took 34 mins. Total time of 1 hour and 39mins. Total material consumed was 20 grams and at $.05 US dollars it works out to be $1 US dollars total. Now, if the Raspberry Pi team delivers a small version that cost will be reduced. I tried to implement a few design features such as the internal retention clip, internal standoffs, internal sliding rails(So, Side B is contained in 5 DOF, leaving 1 DOF free), etc. However, I did not go overboard because I don't have an Alpha Raspberry Pi to fit for form and function. The retention clip needs to be be more aggressive, in addition the standoffs need some work. Plus, the actual walls might need to be a little bit thicker but not much or maybe go with a corrugated design, thinking JU-52. Also, I don't like the fit of the joint between Side A and Side B and might go to an overlapping joint.
Download and print it if you want, but it probably won't do much good.

This is a remix of the FireFly Version and an alternative frame for the Blade NanoQX (also FPV).
It fits the original NQX Cam or the additional Spektrum Micro Cam. Its available for 6mm, 7mm and 8.5mm Motors.
You can bend the camera holder if you heat it up a bit, but be careful. Frame size is at ~110 mm diagonal (m2m) and about 9 x 9 cm in length and width.
Frame weighs between 6g and 7g.

I wanted to build a Star Trek phaser model that could fit nicely on a 485 printer. This print is hollow, and is made with customization in mind. It also has a removable Hand Phaser Type I. The following parts are print in place and will accommodate accessory electronics:
trigger_12 (for a momentary switch),
switch_13 (for a rotary switch or potentiometer),
phasertopparta_6 (two dials, a pushbutton, an LED + whatever you need to hold it in place)
mainbody_3 (for a potentiometer, ‘switch_13’, ‘trigger_12’)
They were modeled with the parts I had lying around in mind, so you might need to make adjustments for your own parts. You will also need a couple of ballpoint pen springs(~.1” *.5”) to assemble the following parts:
phasertopparta_6
phasertoppinion_10
pinioncover_11
I’ve included a diagram of how they fit together. This allows Hand Phaser Type I to be separated from Hand Phaser Type II. Finally, there’s a square hole right above the muzzle. The prop needs a small tinted glass/plastic insert to go there. I’ve included ‘resinpart_9’ for the muzzle insert(clear blue in the big picture) I’d recommend using it to make a mold and cast the part in clear resin. Or you can just print with clear 3D printing filament. Either way works. Please note that Hand Phaser Type II has many print in place parts, most notably in mainbody_3. I’ve included ‘buttoncover_4’ to cover this part. You can see it in the first diagram in gold. It’s literally a button. The tolerance should be pretty high, but your mileage may vary. Please leave feedback if you try it out for yourself, and I will continue to improve the models! Update 1: The pinion cover was actually not properly made. So it has been remade. Update 2: The pinion dovetailing was a cute idea that 3d printers hated. It should be stable enough with just the little pin that goes into the pinion cover. Pinion cover was not very structurally stable. Now it's more stable. The pins to mesh it with the phaser top are now bigger and hopefully stronger. The phaser top part A has had some work done to get greater clearance in the print in place button. Should be able to actually slide a pushbutton into place. Also the muzzle has been repaired after some weird glitch. Update 3: Added some more files. A grate with bigger features because I realized my printer at least couldn't print the very tiny grate originally supplied. Made some dummy parts for the main body knob and the two knobs on the phaser part. These parts are definitely a work in progress but I cannot really find a good detailed photo yet so I made them based on what I could see.

title: Budget Enclosure From Plastic Drain Pipe

description.text:
This is an end cap to fit standard 65mm square plastic pipe commonly used in the UK for rainwater down pipes from roof guttering.
There seemed to be few good enclosures in my local hobby store. They did have a few but they were unrealistically priced. This provides a solution for cheap prototype enclosures for small projects.  
The end cap is provided as a plain cap. It is expected that you will be able to use it as either a plain blanking plate or modify it to allow the fitting of switches, connectors, brackets or anything else you like.
It should be a reasonably good press fit, but you will find that different sections of pipe do vary so you may need to make minor adjustments. Usually a firm hand will make it fit. If not then some hot water can often soften PLA sufficiently to allow assembly.
To permanently attach the end plate to a plastic pipe you may consider an epoxy glue. However a small hole and a grub screw on each side should make the assembly easier to dismantle if ever required. 
As with all my designs, I have provided the original design files in FREECAD format. FREECAD is available for free for major operating systems (Win-XX, Max, Linux and maybe a few others). So it should be easy to modify to fit whatever pipes you have to hand.

description.text: yoyo. Please post makes.

This is a prototype/experiment for a phase-change material thermal mass structure for fitting around a stove pipe (or other pipe) to recover and store waste heat.
The PCM chamber is constructed such that it acts somewhat like a thermal diode to deliver heat into the room, but resist back-flow back out the pipe.  (Or, at least, that's the goal of the experiment.)
I have not yet done any testing with this.  If you do, or if you have any suggestions, let me know!

To actually build this, the conductors would be machined out of a material such as aluminum.
The insulation parts would then be cast out of some kind of ceramic insulation.
The whole mess would then be adhered together with silicone, with the chamber filled with a PCM material such as: paraffin wax, coconut oil, or sodium sulfate decahydrate.

"Thermal Diode"?? One part of the electronic->thermal analogy that has always been lacking in my mind is the concept of a "diode", that is, some device that allows heat to flow only in one direction (e.g. into a room, but not back out). This is one possible means of achieving that, where the solid/liquid boundary of the PCM discourages heat flow in the reverse direction. (Or, at least, that's the idea.)

title: CTC Replicator 2 (and other Makerbot Clones) Display Guard

description.text:
(If you have just received your CTC or other clone of the Makerbot, I recommend you possibly make this your First print to protect your printer from accidental damage. It's easy to make, looks good, and it's to easy to wait and be sorry later you didn't fit this....It's a Very important, must have item). Having just received a CTC Printer one of the things I noticed was the exposed terminals on the back of the display screen just inside the case. Not wanting to have the Printer damaged I decided one of the first things to print was a cover for the back of the display. So here it is. Hopefully this will fit the other Makerbot type clones as well as the CTC printer. It's a nice snug fit in the recess and just pushes in to place and is easy to remove if you ever need to.
Enjoy.... And keep your printer safe... :)
Kim..
(I printed mine on the CTC Makerbot Dual clone using PLA 190' and a bed temp of 57')

CTC Makerbot Dual Clone (Rep 2)

No

No

Standard

10%

comments.text: Hi lincolnwit24s, I use PLA, and have been printing on Glass for a couple of years now. I found that as long as the glass is freshly washed and dried, the prints stick fine to it. If the thing I'm printing is tall or only has thin walls where it's mounted on the glass, I wipe the glass over with Clear Vinegar while it's heating up to improve the grip. I expect it will work with ABS, but I haven't tried. One thing I have found, is that removing the print under running cold water can make the print contract so quickly that it may pull a small bit of glass off the surface. The Glass I use is just plain 3mm Float Glass (I have a glass shop 100yds away), and it costs pennies. I normally buy 2 or 3 bits at a time it's so cheap.
comments.author: KimBrown

comments.text: awesome i dropped an allenkey on the terminals and the display went all funny. i was going to make something to fill the hole but i just put somw tape over it for now.

comments.text: Hi Glad you like this cover. I plan to do some more designs for the printer over the next few weeks. I know that sinking feeling when you wish you could turn the clock back, so that was why I designed the cover early on. I hope it wasn't to expensive for you to fix. I've only had this printer a few days, but am Loving It (I have two other types of printers I have access to, and this is by far the easiest to use....Once you get the software setup that is).

Hey i just recieved the same printer today and hoping you can hell, searched all online, i wish there was a subreddit full of help haha, I have tried many temperatures, re leveled the board thingy several times, i have been at it 12 hours, non stop i am not even kidding ha, and a total of 0 succesful prints, i can not get it to stick to the board, pla or abs, also when it does stick when it goes to other layers the other plastic sticks to the extruder and ends up being a big ball of wibbly wobbly timey wimey, stuff

comments.text: I bought a picture frame at walmart...$4 . Use the glass over the original print bed..no use for that tape. Hold it down with clips you find in the office supply section.......youtube ----abs juice. Make some of that...spread it around on the print bed..prints always stick perfect for me. I'm a newbie...just had my ctc a week now. To clean off the glass after a print is finished..I just run hot water in the sink ofver the glass...the abs juice comes right off. always dry the glass before sticking back onto the print bed..then clip it back down ..good to go always

A holder for a 200mm wide kapton roll. It allows kapton to be applied to the glass of a heated printer bed without bubbles.
The design consists of hubs to fit into the kapton reel and brackets to support the reel and a remote M8 threaded rod.
In operation the tape is pulled from the reel and attached to the threaded rod (see pictures). The glass is then held up to the tape at the threaded rod end and the tape pressed onto the glass. the tape is then progressively rubbed down onto the glass working from the centre to the edge and from the threaded rod to the reel. Cut the tape flush at each and and squeegee down securely to finish.
Having tried several methods (including soap film) I am surprised by how well this works.

Printer:

Disegna3D V4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

14%

Notes: Printed in PLA

For the base I used 9mm MDF which I laser cut, I have included a DXF file for the baseboard.
Attach 2 nuts at one end of the threaded rod and lock them together, there is a pocket in one of the brackets for the threaded rod. Inserting the inside of the locked nuts into this pocket will prevent the threaded rod rotating. All the brackets have nut traps for M4 nuts. The ideal screws to fasten the brackets to the baseboard (assuming it's 9mm thick) are M4x16.

remixed_from.author: AprilStorm
remixed_from.title: Poe Dameron's Blaster from Star Wars the Force Awakens

description.text:
Note: Unless you are a certified masochist, do not attempt to print this just yet! This design is unproven, untested, and unknown results are sure to follow! You have been warned! Enjoy!! I loved some components of the Adafruit blaster, but have been a fan of the German p08 Luger for a long time. Combined with another blaster design I liked, I decided to try to combine them all into a functional laser pistol. This design uses a 12mm laser module and associated heat sink., for example mine uses a 1.8W I picked up from amazon on the cheap :) 1.8 Laser Module (yeah, they have higher power :) ):
http://www.amazon.com/Copper-445nm-Module-X-Drive-405-G-2/dp/B00UEBX08O/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1447624450&sr=8-1&keywords=1.8W+laser+module Protective Eyewear (if you play with lasers and don't have these, then you deserve a Darwin Award!! Seriously!! No F*ING JOKE!) !!!!
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B009T6RN0G?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00 Heatsink:
http://www.amazon.com/Professional-Aluminum-Cooling-Heatsink-heatsink3/dp/B00TUVBOCI/ref=pd_rhf_dp_p_img_6?ie=UTF8&refRID=18Y4HM4MY1C6M3X47YGJ Batteries:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01488KC3O?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00 You'll need these if you don't have em (min 25, more is always better):
4-40 x 3/8" SS Machine Screws
4-40 hex nuts
No.4 lock washers (optional) files, sandpaper, Dremel, Sugru, you know... the basics. plus any stray odds annd ends you want to glue on :) For example, the flared barrel tip is made of spare e-cig parts - heh. This 'thing' is FAR from perfect at this time! Some work remains to be done here, for sure. Until I modify them and get them reposted here, most missing pieces can be found on the Adafruit blaster page. Likewise, the Luger grips can be pulled from the Luger P-08 source page, until I can rework them for the LP-08 Laser Pistol. Also, there are bound to be SERIOUS balance issues! Sheesh, its an early prototype whattaya want?

author: sb43201

description.text:
My phone takes pretty good pictures, but I find the quality slips when I can't keep it stable.  This mount allows me to clip the phone onto my Gorillapod, giving me the stability I need.  Being able to gorilla my phone to a post is also pretty neat.
I'm particularly happy with how the insert clip turned out.  This mount will slide in and lock in place, just like the native part.  (I've also broken the clip out into it's own scad in case you'd like to design your own Gorillapod-compatible thing.)
The included stl is for the Samsung Galaxy S (my phone,) but this is a parametric model, so you can change dimensions to suit your needs. If you leave a comment with your phone and dimensions that worked, I'll put up an STL so that future users won't need to muck with the scad.
UPDATE:  I pulled the iphone4 dimensions off the apple website and added an stl because, you know, the iphone is popular.  Please let me know if it works
Because it's being printed on its side, the clip may need a little x-acto work on the bottom edge, especially on the rounded corner.  After that, you should get a nice snug fit that's easy to remove.

comments.text: Nice scad file, modified the values to fit my iPhone6s+ perfectly, though I had to open the model in a different program to add fillets, rounded corners save print time and makes prints more sturdy: http://i.imgur.com/74fVGyF.png Some way to do this in the .scad would be nice.

I was playing with some lenses and my iPhone 6 and found that some were good for Macro photography. But I needed a way to hold the lens firmly in place. John Umekubo had a good friction fit design posted on 123d's models site that I adapted to fit my iPhone6 Plus. It fits over the existing case, but is flexible enough that I believe it would work without a case too. 
As you can see in the photos, you can get really close to an object, but as with most macro photography, the depth of field is shallow. The lens I used will show a vignette on the iPhone preview, I zoom the screen a bit to make the view expand to the entire screen.  
I adapted the lens holder to fit a lens that I scavenged from some discarded CCTV cameras. It might be worth a call to some local security companies in your area to see if they have any old analog cameras and lenses they could part with. They are practically useless now, because everything is going digital. You'll have to change the adapter to fit whatever lens you come up with, I'm sure. So I've included the 123dDesign file.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes: Printed in PLA. I would think any filament type would work just fine.

Remixed from 123D design by John Umekubo Original design is here: http://www.123dapp.com/123D_Design/Macro-Lens-Holder-iPhone-6/4114876
I had to make his adapter wider, and put a 10mm hole further down the back of it. This allowed the lens I had to friction fit the hole and center itself on the existing iPhone camera lens.

comments.text: Yes they were fairly wide angle surveillance cameras used for banks and ATMs. The lens pictured actually has a lens in front and 2 lenses in back of a short tube. So it's a "lens system" I guess you'd say, not a single piece of glass. It's 13mm long, and 9mm in diameter. It's been awhile since I took it apart. But I'd say it was the final assembly of the original zoom lens that focused the image on the CMOS image sensor of the camera. Best of luck with your project!

description.text:
I started with whosawhatsis's Minimalistic Mk7 replacement for the dimensional data and then recreated the design in SW compatible software. I have provided solidworks, step, and stl files for ease of redesign (sorry no .scad, use FreeCad if you need to get back to scad) which should make this easier for others to redesign.
Remix features: larger diameter spring seat holes, larger filament slot/hole in the lever arm with an added support in the middle of the slot, small fillet added to the bottom & top printing surfaces to make the print edges uniform, and an overall smoothing & refining of all features. I also separated the parts, you can put them back together with your slicing software if needed.
I have not printed these yet. I will update here after I have.

author: RustyKnight

title: Robust Flight Camera Pan Assembly for FPV Flying Wings

description.text:
This is a fairly robust yet reasonably lightweight pan assembly for a FPV flight camera. It was designed and intended for a Chimera Flying Wing for FPV, but can certainly be used for other craft as well. Here's a flight video of it in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bapxTDwmhos Required Parts List, in addition to the (4) printed parts:
(1) Turnigy TGY-R5180MG 180 Degree MG Analog Servo. http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=65966
(1) Surveilzone HS1184 28x28mm Sony Super HAD CCD 600TVL Mini Camera http://www.surveilzone.com/28x28mm-Sony-Super-HAD-CCD-600TVL-Mini-Camera-Alloy-Case-g-1380
(4) M3 nylon lock nuts
(4) M3 bolts
(4) Small screws to attach the servo horn to the top pan assembly. I cannot guarantee that this pan will work with other servos. I do know it would need modifications to accomodate the RMRC 260 deg servo. I highly recommend the above Turnigy servo as it's inexpensive, provides a smooth pan between steps, and has about +/-130 degrees of rotation if the transmitter endpoints are set to +/- 125% (800 to 2200us pulse width). I tried the RMRC 260 deg servo, and while it had better torque, it was slower and the steps were not nearly as smooth. As far as the camera, others will certainly work, but I selected this one because it uses the same sensor as the PZ0420 which works very well for FPV, but it's smaller and has a fairly lightweight alloy case which is great for minimizing UHF interference. Here are the STL files for the pan assembly. There are 4 parts:

  • The plane "base" mount. It's designed to be printed with the captive nut holes facing upwards. Use M3 nylon lock nuts in this. I put in a drop of CA glue to hold them in place. This part gets physically bonded to the plane after cutting out foam in the nose. I used hot glue, but contact cement like uhu-por might be even better.

  • A servo shim plate. It's thin and does what you think it does - acts as a shim between the plane base mount and the base of the actual pan assembly.

  • The lower part of the pan assembly.

  • The upper pan assembly. This is intended to be printed with the cylinder groove upwards.
    • I printed everything in 0.2mm layer height in ABS. I wouldn't recommend PLA since it warps easily in a hot car (been there, done that with a 3D printed tricopter...it's not worth the risk). The parts fit very snugly and you'll probably need to file and/or sand them down to get a good fit between the upper and lower pan assemblies. You'll probably want to sand the top of each race flat as well. Once it rotates somewhat freely, clean away the excess grains of plastic with isopropyl alcohol. Then, use synthetic grease in the groove. I use Tri-flo. Again, it should rotate 360 degrees smoothly and without binding. If I recall correctly, the total weight of the pan assembly (minus the servo and the camera) is 35g. If you want to save weight, you can forego the lower plane mount piece and shim, and screw in the servo to the lower pan assembly using screws through the servo ears. That will reduce the pan assembly weight to around 25g. I like the option of being able to remove the pan assembly in case it breaks, though, so it can be replaced without re-gluing it to the plane. A bit of background: I designed this because I wasn't satisfied with any of the inexpensive pan systems I found on the market, which typically bear the entire weight of the camera on a servo horn. Such a design, while lightweight, not only results in camera vibration, but the mechanism is prone to breaking where the horn is attached to the servo during a rough landing or a crash. This design is intended to minimize the stress on the servo axis and horn through the use of the larger diameter cylinder which tracks in a groove. The design isn't perfect, and I haven't crash tested it yet, but it certainly feels like it would hold up better. An improvement would be the addition of bearings, but honestly, I'm not sure it needs it as it moves very smoothly after sanding down the surfaces and applying synthetic grease.

Printer:

MendelMax 1.5+

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm or smaller layer heights

Infill:

30% or higher

Notes: Strongly recommend ABS or a high glass transition plastic. You don't want to use PLA as it could warp in a car on a hot day!

I strongly recommend building the entire assembly before bonding the bottom plane mount to your RC aircraft. Assembly Instructions:

  • Clean up the printed parts with a hobby knife. There will likely be an unwanted bridge in the lower pan assembly where the servo body passes through - cut this away.

  • Sand down the top and bottom pan cylinder races flat, and then the grooves until binding no longer occurs. I allowed for 0.1 or 0.15mm gaps between the top and bottom pan assemblies in the design. The fit is intended to be tight. Hand files from Harbor Freight work very well for removing excess material from the grooves. If everything moves freely, clean the grooves with isopropyl alcohol, dry, and add some synthetic grease (e.g. Tri-Flo) to the appropriate surfaces. The pan should now "glide" on the grease as it rotates.

  • Install the (4) M3 nylon lock nuts in the plane base mount. I put in a drop of CA glue to hold them in place.

  • Test fit the servo in the lower pan assembly. The ears should sit nearly flush to the bottom (might be a 0.5mm gap).

  • Test fit the servo in the shim and lower pan assembly.

  • Install the 4-ear servo horn in the upper pan assembly. You'll need to cut the longer ears down to the length of the smaller ones. Use some small screws that can bite into both plastics. The heads of the screws should be on the top of the flat surface. For additional peace of mind, use a little bit of adhesive (although I didn't).

  • Test the entire assembly using a servo tester. Center the servo using the tester and attach the horn screw. You might want to use a drop of blue loctite to keep it from backing out.

  • Install the "U" mount to the top of the pan assembly. I used small hex bolts (M1.5 or M2, can't recall) and nuts. Locite should be applied here if using fasteners.

  • Fasten together the lower 3 layers with the M3 bolts. Everything should be together now, minus the camera.

  • Attach the camera to the metal "U" mount using the screws that came with the camera. I highly recommend using washers to increase the surface area grip to prevent the camera from undesired tilting while in flight, and also the use of blue locite. You'll likely want a 5 to 10 degree down angle for the camera.

  • Let the locite dry, and make sure everything works!

  • If necessary, cut cavities into the R/C craft. Make sure to cut one for the servo, too. Do a test fit and check for clearance at all pan angles. In my Chimera, I simply used a sharp hobby knife.

  • Bond the lower plane mount bracket to the plane (or other R/C craft). To prevent seepage of adhesive into the multiple layers, you might want to remove the (4) M3 bolts and just bond the plane mount piece. I recommend either hot glue or contact adhesive such as UHU-POR.

  • I strongly recommend using some sort of strain relief for the video feed cable. You don't want stress on the non-locking connector that most FPV cameras have. I simply cut a 1" mounting block down to about 3/4" on one side, attached that to the back of the camera, looped the video feed cable in a "U", and zip-tied it. That way, when the camera pans, the stress is on the zip-tie point rather than the connection point. There I'm sure that there are better ways to do it, though, so I'll leave it to you folks :).
    • Enjoy, and happy FPV'ing!

author: petethered

description.text:
Most of the Flashforge Dreamer models I see online don't have the metal grill, it seems like this was added to later models. If yours didn't come with these, you may not have the appropriate screw lengths to use this replacement grill. If you DO have one of these models, you might have noticed that the screws holding these on runs to the back and secures the extruders. The problem is the grill just goes over the fan holes and never makes a good solid contact with anything. This causes a lot of problems:
  • You can't tighten the screws down securely,
  • If you tighten too much, the grill warps/bends outwards/hits the fan blades,
  • it looks really sloppy. Can't believe they let it out the door without some spacers.
    • I suppose I could have just made a few small spacers to place in the fan holes and called it a day, but I don't like the look of the chrome guards. It has a very 1990s look to it.

Printer:

Flashforge Dreamer

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: The supports for this are minimal, just two tiny spots where the screws countersink into the face of the grill. I'd recommend putting them in place, can't hurt anything and the screws cover any ugliness.

Screw hole width I found the screw holes to be too tight after printing, but I liked how well the printer handled the posts as far as infill goes so I left it as is. You WILL need to widen these out slightly, a 1/8" drill bit on super low speed (esp if using PLA) cleans these out to the perfect size.
Designed in a few minutes in Tinkercad.com

I like to watch TV shows on the Lifefitness treadmills at my office.  My Surface tablet and iPad sat too low on the machines to comfortably watch them.  
I made a thing that could hold my iPad or Surface above the top of the machine.  This not only makes it much more comfortable to watch, but also allows the runner to see the data display simultaneously.  It works very well for that limited purpose.

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Solidoodle 2 - Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Notes: Since the final appearance didn't really matter, I didn't worry about it. I used blue PLA filament in my ancient Solidoodle, and the final product doesn't look that great, but it's worked now for almost a year.
Extra firm grip I added some duct tape to the device to hold the tablet even better.
It was pretty easy I measured the treadmill and my tablet and whipped it up in Sketchup. First printing was a success, which is a good thing because my Solidoodle seems to be jammed.

description.text:
These are some intake ducts I designed for a Printrbot Simple Metal.
I don't expect much in terms of a performance increase from them - I just thought it would look cool, and act as a decent "grill" of sorts for the intake. Personally, I prefer the one with the single support arm, but I've provided both! My exhaust duct is from here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:356001 Please feel free to add pictures of your "Makes"!

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

20

Notes: I suggest printing with a higher infill - at least 25% or so.
Mine was printed with a 0.15mm layer height, using the "brim" option in Cura. This required using an exacto knife to take the edges off after printing. However, it should be able to be printed on a well-prepared surface without a problem. You may still want to trim the bottom of the inside edge of the duct though.
Print with the duct facing up. No supports necessary.

When installing, you're going to want to take all the screws out, put them in the duct separate from the printer, then put the duct on with all four screws on it.
I highly recommend using a ball headed allen key. It will make it easier to not damage the duct when tightening the screws.
Also, I think an acetone vapor treatment would work wonders on one of these - that's on my list of projects.

Notes: the walls are thin and I wanted them as solid as possible, so I used 50% infill. Print upside down and it will print with minimal support. (only under the bridge to the cable strain relief.

Again, after trying lots of printed extruders i decided to make something simple, strong, durable and flexible enough to accept different kinds of filaments, both 3mm and 1.75mm, also different types and sizes of idler/gear/bolt combo but using only M3 screws like all my designs. I added reinforcements on some places to maximize toughness and also to expand possible number of push fits to use. Toughest part is to obtain proper tension or more specific finding right spring to use.

Printer:

meta.frame.XL

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3-0.5

Infill:

80-100

Notes: tested on few printers, these print just fine with no problems but also are in use for some time now, also no single problem noticed.

Assembly requires some drilling to make it fit just right on your chosen idler bolt. i used M3 for all needs but just because i had M3 ball bearings doesn't mean you have it too. make idler as snug as you can, also feel free to make some careful scalpel cuts if you have any friction anywhere. I regret on hassle but it simply was required to be able to use this universal all round. Push fit is carefully heated and screwed in place firmly and precisely, then you cement it with some super or hot glue to give it firm position, take care that push fit is centered properly before cementing it so filament can be driven with simple move instead of hitting in wall or something else. Hardest part to get right is spring. My general rule of thumb is for 3mm filament using toughest spring that fits and than shortening it until i get required output. Also found out that 1.75 mm fiaments can also work well with same tension levels.

comments.text: greetings Robert K83LNN and thanks for your comment, must be nice to have ability to measure this. I am limited to touch sensing when judging strength of printed part. Actually when i make parts for usage like this i tend to give it at least 90% infill along with more trail overlap and some over extrusion so there is not much room for glue, using this method i get very firm printed parts which work nice with printers and such. I also heard of using epoxy with vacuum pressure on part that needs more punch but have not tested this just yet. Maybe will try both your method and epoxy one next CNC mill i will be making.
comments.author: FloydAgain

comments.text: I found that with the problem with a part being weak is I drill a small hole in the places that I want make more stronger and inject Gorilla Glue into the holes and as this stuff cures it expands into the honeycomb part. As a result it is super strong. I know I have been doing this for a year now. I even printed up two test cubes about 20 mm. and injected only one and did a crush test and the one with no filler failed at about 125 Lbs. of presser while the injected one showed some sings of stress at around 900 Lbs. I could not go much more cause I am limited to 1000 psi. Hope that this will help.And great work. Have a great day ! :-)

author: Lukevisser

description.text:
This is a parametric bracket generator for MakeBlock which can generate parts of various sizes. All MakeBlock structural parts use M4 screws with the holes separated by an 8mm pitch, so I created this generator to generate flat parts with a specified number of holes in the x and y directions (as well as the part thickness). Most printers close inner holes up a bit, so a 2mm radius will create a part where the M4 screws "bite", and 2.4mm radius will create one where they're loose and need a nut. You can also create longer openings within the part (such as I did in the 3x9 part) by adding the "open" row or column to the appropriate "open_" array, starting at column/row zero. For example, to make a 3x3 part with a cross in it, put 1 in the open_xs and 1 in the open_ys with rows=3 and columns=3. For multiple rows or column, separate with commas, (eg. 0,1,2). Note that you can create islands with this feature, so be careful. MakeBlock is a hobby robotics platform which spans from kids learning bots to advanced self-balancing bots, 3-d printers, robot arms, engravers, and more. If you create a new Thing with Customizer, please name it descriptively. v2: Version 2 increases thickness to 3mm as per the original parts. It also has less rounding on the exterior corners. Finally, it centers the part on the origin so it transfers easily to MakerWare.
v3: Modular code. Lets you set corner radius and pitch independently. STL files are identical.
v4: Make it easier to create right-angle corners (corner_radius=0).
v5: Expose additional parameters in Customizer.
v6: Add comment for Customizer to use 2.4mm radius for "loose" parts
v7: You can now specify long open rows or columns in Customizer with a comma-separated list. For L-Shaped Parts, see my MakeBlock Parametric L Bracket.

The wrapped toothed belt saves the need to clean up the plastic printed toothed feature that is even worse on low quality printers. BOM:

title: HTC One M8 Phone Holder for Mazda 3 i Grand Touring or Hatchback

description.text: This is a two part phone holder. I split it to make it easier to print, and to allow the clip part to be mounted to the car dash (using double sided tape) without committing to the phone holder. The idea is to be able to swap out just the phone holder part when I get a new phone. I wanted this device to blend in with the car's dash board as much as possible. It doesn't cover any buttons or restrict airflow when the phone isn't installed. When I bought my 2015 Mazda I Grand Touring hatchback I quickly realized I wanted a way to hold my HTC One M8 phone in a convenient place. Even though I have a built in GPS unit, google maps on my phone does a better job of doing voice searches, and leaving my phone in the cup holder cuts down the reception. I noticed that there is an excellent spot for a phone in the center of my dash, just over the emergency light button. As I have a Form 1+ at work, I decided to make my own holder. I wanted it to be easy to clip the phone into place, without the extra clamps or sliding mechanisms required with all universal phone mounts. This holder is designed to work with most slip line phone cases, but the one I happen to have is this one: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00IJ0R02Y?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_search_detailpage. After six prototype builds, I finally got all the dimensions perfect. If you happen to be in my situation and want a kick ass phone holder, try making this one. I haven't tested it yet, but this should work with an HTC M9 phone (with a case on it) as well. It should be printable on most 3D printers.

Another 80's G.I. Joe toy for the collection.  I always liked the way the A.P.C. looked but I didn't have it as a kid - so this isn't a perfect copy.  I used pictures and some reasonable guesses to model it.  As usual, the model was created in the original size of the toy but this model was optimized to be printed in the 25% range.
The chassis should be printed with supports, the rest of the pieces can be done without.  I could have made the chassis, canvas, and turret as one model but they are easier to paint as separate pieces.  Tires are printed with the hubcaps 'up' and then glued on.
Much respect and gratitude to the men and women of our Armed Forces (past and present).  Your sacrifice allows people like me to live in peace and freedom.  /You/ are the real American heroes.

This file is a free download.  Please note that it is listed as “non-commercial”.  Neither you nor I are allowed to buy or sell physical copies of this 3D model.   You are allowed (and encouraged) to print copies for your own personal use.  If you have been re-directed to this file from a source other than my site on thingiverse.com they have done so without my permission.  Thank you for respecting the rights of the original copyright holder.

At this point I still consider this a work in progress. 
This is my attempt to mount an E3d v6 on my printrbot without using the printed adapter that is usually glued to the top of the E3d and clamped into the extruder. 
In the end I was able to get the E3d to mount fully into the Printrbot extruder without making any changes to the E3d. To do this however I need to drill out a small area on the underside of the filament feed hole on the extruder for the plastic bowden ring on the E3d to fit. This allowed the E3d to slide all the way up into the printrbot extruder. I also needed to make an adapter bracket out of 1.8mm aluminum sheet. This is needed to be done because there is only about 4mm between the bottom of the extruder and the top cooling fan, so there is not enough room for a screw head and enough support from a printed part. 
The "1102_for_E3d" part is the main part of this modification. It replaces the entire front end of the stock 1405 Y-axis. It also holds the extruder lower than the stock location in order to account for the shorter hotend.

comments.text: Hey, not to get you down, but you can actually install the e3d without all the mods, just have to wedge it in and seriosly tighten the screws. That is how i did it and it seems ot work fine! Otherwise, thats a great design.
comments.author: DMC3d_and_more

comments.text: It's fine, I knew I could just clamp the top portion of the e3d into the bottom portion of the extruder and it  probably be good enough. There was a couple of things that i didn't like about this method though. I've heard that the nema 17 screw holes are fairly easy to strip, but you need to tighten the screws down a lot if you don't want to run the risk of the hotend falling out the bottom of the extruder (if the screw loosens, then nothing is holding it in). This puts a lot of guess work into how tight the clamping screw should be. I really wanted to see if I could get the hotend all the way up into the extruder, which would allow me to use the clamping screw to lock the hotend in place (i.e. the hotend physically won't come out unless the clamping screw is completely removed). Overall it might have been a little bit overkill, but it's nice to not have to worry about the hotend falling out.

The House Ratta Sling Trike was an old design I made for an awesome old setting called House of Strife. I've had this setting on my mind recently as a way to test the vehicle rules in Wayfarer Tactics. So, I revived some old House Ratta stuff and will use it to do just that. The Sling Trike is fast and mean! It's also dangerous as hell as it's open top and lacks sufficient safety precautions in favor of just a little more speed. The followers of Xaot care not for safety...only the glory of dying in a good fight! We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested to help fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Wayfarer Tactics. Check it out here. Thank you for looking!

description.text:
It takes me couples of weeks to print an 1kg filament spool out. Since the weather of Taipei is humid, filament spools on the back of Replicator 2X would absorb enough moisture to affect the filament quality really quick. To keep the print quality of filament, I designed this spool system to protect filament spools from moisture and dust. It works for spools from MakerBot, might not work for spools from other brands. I have attached spool_system.scad, which requires the following two awesome libraries. Thanks to aubenc!
  • polyScrewThread.scad (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8796)
  • knurledFinishLib.scad (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9095)

I printed the following stl files with infill 20%, shells 3, and layer height 0.15. Enabled raft and supports for part1.stl only.
  • part1.stl x 2
  • part2.stl x 2
  • part3.stl x 2
  • part4.stl x 2
  • part5_left_extruder_spool.stl x 1
  • part5_right_extruder_spool.stl x 1
    • Additional parts you need.
  • 2 of M6 x 8 bolts
  • duct tape
  • 2 bags of silica gel (100g)
  • humidity indicator x 2 (optional)
  • Sponge
  • 2 of 45cm x 35cm space bag
    • Please checkout attached photos for instructions.

description.text:
ive included the X endstop and Y endstop files. the X endstop is designed for a bowden style carriage with a small contact point on the lower left hand screw on the carriage itself. you will ned to design this until i can remake my file of one. more or less a 5mm spacer. please use electrical tape to cover the back side of the (all) endstop, shorting one will destroy your arduino mega (ask me how i know). the x endstop is held in place by two of the motor mount screws so the endstop itself sits over one of them, if your pulley sticks out of the gantry you may need to modify and remove material from the edge. the Y endstop is held in place by the screw that holds the Y drive lid. i am still working on a proper z endstop servo apparatus but hopefully one will be up shortly. it may be a remix of the bowden carriage that i am using but generic none the less. any ideas, questions or comments, leave them for me. Nearly there
So as you can see from the new picture, it is almost there. I will be uploading endstops Brackets for all axis and A Modified Truss to accept the 12864 display and the NEMA 17 For the bowden configuration. I plan on making this an auto leveling machine so expect to see a servo driven Z endstop as well as a standard post mount. The spool mount included with the original design should work really well in this configuration. I will link the couplers i used as well for the 3/8 rod(multiple options with the design). Any questions or feedback, leave a comment or message me. Another UPDATE
I've split and added the 2Z housing as a male and female puzzle cut, in case you have lost a fair amount of area on your print bed. I have a new belt keeper in the works for use with an opened GT2 belt on the One/Two/Three up X carriage. Keep an eye on my designs, Should be up soon. UPDATE
I've added files for the Bed X Support(Male/Female) so it can be printed in halves that snap together with a puzzle cut, If either of them warp, it may make them a tighter fit, Sanding may help. If this happens get them as close to flush as you can, then use your stove top and heat water up to about 140~ degrees F. once warm and slightly flexible, move it to a flat surface like glass and hold it flat until it cools.
This will help Solve the upgraded gantry issue. My bed is also trimmed down by another 15mm for the time being do to a makeshift belt tensioner. They fit easily, If i rotate them by 30 degrees in the Z axis. Let me know how it goes.
This is also a makeshift way to get it done. While I suggest super glue or friction welding when you assemble it, i can say that the pieces slip together and mate extremely well. Also like i said, makeshift, If you are completing this mod, Print a single piece one once you have the opportunity. These parts allow for the Base to be extended By 40mm In the X Axis, and the Bed to be extended by 40mm for use with 330mm rods. All are printable on the TwoUP, but you may have Trouble printing the BED X SUPPORT if you have an upgraded gantry. You will still need all of the other files from the original builds (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:844471 , http://www.thingiverse.com/proto-plastik/designs). These should also be compatible with the 2Z edition that he has released(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1078143). Leave a comment with questions, or feedback. These were Modified with Tinkercad.

I actually used 4 pieces of plywood 3/4 by 3/4 sticks in a "H" configuration to make a glass support frame . I got a piece of 3/16 glass from an auto glass place for $10 (9"x12") that I made some clamps for. Its a little heavier than window pane so I slowed my acceleration down from the default and that lets it move smoothlier.(?)
Still a work in progress, I have to neaten up the wiring and come up with a cable guide that I like that isn't too bulky.

title: Blower Mount for Bowden Feed Hexagon Hotend V1.0

description.text:
A mount I made to attach a hexagon hot end (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00W8FL5BS?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o09_s00) to a HE3D (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:919038) x-carriage. I've later found out that the HE3D x-carriage is derived from the Prusa i3 Rework. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119616. HE3D seems to have made changes to go to just 2 holes .91" apart from each other in the middle. I have recently remixed a well designed modern version to be compatible with that hole spacing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1133926). This is the 2nd attempt a this this design. The first version (V.0.0)used 2x 40mm axial fans. I couldn't feel the air flow very well from them. I ordered these blowers from digikey at the same time I ordered the fans in case I was unsatisfied with the airflow, which I was. Hooking up the 24 V blowers the difference in airflow is night and day. You can feel it blowing well behind the hexagon heat sink. Cost wise it works out to be about the same. These blowers keep the cold end cold. They do have noise but behind a door it's quiet. Here is a link to the 24V blowers I used. Dikey Part#: 603-1116-ND . https://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/BFB0524HH/603-1116-ND/1014447 BOM:
3D Printed Parts:
Blower_Shrowd_Hot_End_Tip
Mounting_Bracket_Left
Mounting_Bracket_Right
X-Carrriage_Mounting_Bracket
Securing_Plate Of the Shelf (what I wrote down when I built it):
2x BFB 51x51x15MM - Blower Fans - Digikey
10x M4 Nuts
10x M4 Washers
4x M4x25mm Socket Head Cap Screw
2x M4x16mm Socket Head Cap Screw
4x M4x10mm Socket Head Cap Screw I got the hexagon model from GrabCad (https://grabcad.com/library/hexagon-hotend-1). I appreciate Joseph Rafferty posting that. I was having jams with the axial fan version of this and it went away with the blowers. Enjoy.

author: Munchie12

description.text:
This is a caddy that will hold a Philmore 30-2400 Micro snap action switch. (available at Fry's in the US) Switch should press into a cutout on the bottom of the part. It also has a groove for the wires to exit. Caddy will temporarily snap onto the delta Effector around the stock hotend nozzle without having to remove anything. When not in use it will clip around the heat shield above the fan. Use the Normally Open & Common terminals on the switch and connect up to the SEN header on the top of the toolhead. use the center and the right pin on the SEN Connector. The connector you want to get is a Female JST PHR-3 connector. Don't forget to also buy the crimp pins if needed. Right now only the following fork of Repetier firmware supports the Z-Probe on the OLP.
See this forum post http://www.dreammaker.cc/forum/viewtopic.php?f=9&t=259 Accuracy +/- .01%
Probe offset from nozzle X+24mm Y+12mm Z+2mm (See Revisions)
You will most likely have to tweek the Z offset for your setup.

Printer:

Overlord Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm Layer

Infill:

20 %
Built in OnShape.com. posted as a public model.

Rev 1 Did not like the way the offset worked in practice on the first version. So I made this lower bracket to glue on to the bottom of the first bracket. The switch is now located directly below the nozzle. This should make firmware settings easier to work with and you only have to apply a Z offset now. I thought about redoing the whole bracket as a single part, but I think that it would require a bunch of support and would be too hard to print. Z Probe Height offset is about 11.8mm, as usual you will have to tune this number to your own setup. Rev 1.1 Made friction bumps on Upper bracket bigger. Decreased the amount of tollarance between brackets because it was pulling the arms in on upper bracket.

author: Revolve3D

description.text:
Following the terrorist attack of Paris on Friday the 13th of November 2015, a French artist Jean Jullien published a now iconic image onto social media combining the Eiffel Tower and the widely used symbol for peace (formally called the CND symbol). This image has spread quickly to now represent public support for France as it recovers from the disaster. 
Print your own and place it somewhere public or add it to your key ring to show your support of French recovery! Don't forget to publish a photo in the "I Made One" section!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

15

Notes: Printed in about 30 minutes on standard settings. Adhesion should not be a problem so a raft is probably not needed.
This is a simplified version of the graphic of the one made by Jean Jullien. I did not replicate the original exactly as it may be against copyright and it can be difficult to print on some machines.
